intro: Bryonia corsica, commonly known as the Corsican bryony, is a climbing plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Cucurbitaceae, which includes cucumbers and squashes. The plant produces large, heart-shaped leaves and yellow flowers that bloom in the summer. Its most distinctive feature is the spiny, orange-colored fruit that matures in late summer. Bryonia corsica is often found in rocky or coastal areas and has been used historically in traditional medicine.
